items.title: Slow patient intake during high-urgency situations
items.description: Intake nurses need extremely fast data entry when patients arrive in critical condition. Typing detailed information creates dangerous delays during triage of urgent patients.
items.impact: Delays in initial patient processing, especially for urgent cases

items.title: Waiting room bottleneck between intake and triage
items.description: Patients experience significant wait times (10+ minutes) between intake completion and being called to triage, creating anxiety and workflow inefficiency.
items.impact: Patient dissatisfaction, increased anxiety, inefficient resource utilization

items.title: Poor UX for gloved/sanitized hands
items.description: Clinical staff wearing gloves or with sanitized hands struggle with tiny UI elements, text links, and precise mouse clicks. Physical constraints of medical environment not accommodated.
items.impact: Slower data entry, errors, frustration, potential infection control issues

items.title: Privacy violations with patient name displays
items.description: Current systems display full patient names on public boards, creating GDPR and HIPAA violations. This is non-negotiable compliance requirement.
items.impact: Legal liability, regulatory violations, patient privacy breach

items.title: Patient anxiety with numeric-only identification
items.description: Using only ticket numbers causes patients to forget their identifiers, lose paper slips, and feel dehumanized ('like cattle'). Creates significant patient experience issues.
items.impact: Patient anxiety, confusion, feeling dehumanized, poor experience

items.title: Internet dependency creates system failure risk
items.description: Cloud-based systems fail when internet connectivity is lost during storms or outages, but internal LAN remains operational. Cannot afford to lose waiting list data.
items.impact: Complete system outage, loss of patient queue, manual fallback required

items.title: Display lag causes patient confrontation
items.description: When doctors update patient status, any delay in public display update (even 1-2 seconds) causes patients to knock on glass and confront staff, creating disruption.
items.impact: Patient confrontation, staff disruption, perceived system failure

items.title: Bright screens hurt night shift staff
items.description: Bright white screens cause eye strain and discomfort for staff working night shifts. No dark mode available in current systems.
items.impact: Eye strain, fatigue, reduced efficiency, health concerns
items.frequency: Every night shift (approximately 30% of operational hours)

items.title: Aggressive bright public displays at night
items.description: Bright white TV displays in waiting rooms at night (3 AM) are aggressive and uncomfortable for waiting patients and families in dim environments.
items.impact: Patient discomfort, poor experience, sensory overload

items.title: Zero training time requirement for float staff
items.description: When regular staff take vacation and float nurses cover, there is no time for training. System must be completely intuitive and learnable in 30 seconds or staff cannot use it effectively.
items.impact: Float staff cannot perform effectively, errors increase, workflow disruption
items.frequency: Weekly (vacation coverage, sick days, shift changes)

items.title: Countdown timers cause patient riots
items.description: Displaying countdown timers (e.g., '59:59') on public boards causes extreme patient anxiety and confrontational behavior ('riots'). Creates unsafe and stressful environment.
items.impact: Patient aggression, confrontations, unsafe environment, staff stress
items.current_workaround: Avoid countdown timers, use category-based display

items.title: Automated escalation ignores clinical judgment
items.description: Automated systems that escalate patient priority based on wait time alone are dangerous. Algorithms cannot see clinical indicators like profuse sweating or behavioral changes that require human judgment.
items.impact: Inappropriate prioritization, potential patient harm, overrides clinical judgment

items.title: Vendor access requires 2-week approval
items.description: External vendor VPN access requires lengthy 2-week approval process, preventing rapid bug fixes and updates. Must use manual tarball/patch delivery.
items.impact: Delayed bug fixes, slower response to issues, increased manual work
items.current_workaround: Tarball delivery, manual deployment by IT

items.title: Session timeout causes data loss
items.description: Strict 15-minute idle timeout for security compliance can cause loss of partially completed forms, forcing staff to re-enter data and creating frustration.
items.impact: Data loss, rework, staff frustration, potential errors on re-entry
items.frequency: Daily, especially during busy periods with interruptions
items.current_workaround: Staff remember to save frequently, accept data loss
